Award.AwardTitle: Prosodic Systems in New Guinea: Integrating computational and typological approaches to linguistic analysis

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The world's languages make heavy use of prosody--tone, stress, intonation, and length--to communicate meaning, and tone is the most complex of these elements. Although non-tone languages typically exploit pitch for intonational purposes, the more sophisticated use of pitch in tone languages means that speakers of such languages will have quite different mental representations of pitch from speakers of English and better-known European non-tone languages. This project will investigate the tone and reduced-tone languages of New Guinea, a linguistically under-investigated area of the world which is home to a sixth of the world's languages. The project will collect substantial new bodies of recorded and transcribed language data from several undescribed tone languages. It will then use computational and theoretical methods to analyze the geographical distribution of tonal properties and the interaction of tone and other prosodic features.

The project will incorporate technology into linguistic field work and develop an exemplary model of prosodic description. Language consultants will be trained in the model's use, leading to more accessible primary data and more accountable descriptions. The data will be made available in a form that can be readily used by scholars, language teachers, and communities of speakers and will support the development of writing systems and literacy programs for these languages.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Half of the world's languages are tonal and use voice pitch to signal differences in meaning. New Guinea is home to the greatest concentration of the world's languages (approximately 1/6th) and the greatest diversity of language families in the world. It is home to 150-300 tone languages, mostly undocumented. In general, New Guinea is massively under-represented in empirical linguistic work. Computational and corpus-based approaches have introduced a new era of rigor and accountability in linguistics, and are guiding the collection and analysis of data.

This project described and analysed the tone systems of several New Guinea tone languages, involving fieldwork in Papua New Guinea and in the West Papua province of Indonesia. Speakers of New Guinea tone languages were also brought to Australia for a two week workshop at the Australian National University, where their languages were studied intensively by the project investigators and world-leading authorities on tone languages from the US. Further workshops and consulations led to the preparation of an edited collection of studies on the world's tone languages, incorporating a comprehensive set of guidelines for working with tonal languages in general. The guidelines have been incorporated into an open source software tool that supports the elicitation and classification of tones. The workshops, publications, and software have supported research students who are beginning careers in empirical linguistics.
